Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was still buzzing from the morning’s sales call, my numbers already ahead of target for the week. Management would be thrilled, and I could almost hear my supervisor’s praise. But now, standing in the polling station, I was just another citizen, ballot in hand. The poll worker peered at my envelope, frowning at the smudged signature. “Could you please re-sign this? It’s for your vote to count,” she said gently. I hesitated, remembering the strict compliance training at work—never alter a document after the fact, always follow protocol to the letter. My telemarketer instincts screamed at me to avoid anything that might look improper, to protect myself from accusations of tampering. But as a voter, I was expected to trust the process and cooperate with officials. My hand hovered over the pen, heart pounding, caught between the rules drilled into me at work and the instructions of the poll worker. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something different, and I didn’t know which voice to listen to.
